And I think that's real nice of him because black people don't have a very good life, you got to admit that, to be a nigger is sometimes practic'ly fatal, but the wife don't understand all of that, she thinks niggers are just so much dirt, which anybody ought to know better if they been on their ass their ownselves -- and that is the cause of his profound unhappiness, Buddy, that no-good-mean wife with all her Southern prejudice against niggers and everything! It is a very long speech and delivered with a non-stop vitality that leaves Buddy a trifle groggy. Slowly, he shakes his head, as enter Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor is here. And Brother, supper is ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - DINING ROOM - NIGHT A SHOT of the Hillyer family minus Rose eating dinner in the dining room. The meal is almost finished, Daddy cutting apple pie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that Doctor still up there, Brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, he's still up there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's taking the rascal so long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, Dr. Martinson isn't a rascal, he's one of the finest physicians in Glenville. He studied at Johns Hopkins University.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care where the polecat studied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes the negativism and cynicism in you makes me want to vomit. (shakes her head sadly as Buddy surreptitiously puts his napkin on table) Your real trouble is that you're anti-intellectual. The irony is women are supposed to be emotional, but I never saw anybody who depended more on emotion and prejudice than you do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a half audible murmur) Excuse me, gotta go to bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I have a plan about Rose, an educational plan. She's getting better and we don't want any more trouble -- (notices Buddy slipping out) Brother, you ought to hear this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be right back. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Buddy as he slips out during following speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First, those clothes she wears. They're too provocative. I've talked to her a lot about it and I think she understands... INT. HILLYER HOME - FRONT HALL - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Buddy as he goes down the hall, eyes narrowed. ON Buddy posted in the doorway of the living room. He has his hands on his hips Daddy-style and is staring sternly up the stairs. CUT TO A POV SHOT of Dr. Martinson with his black bag in hand and shoulders hunched coming down the stairs. The man is slinking, has quilt written all over him. As he goes down the stairs he glances to one side, sees Buddy and frowns. The man gives a sudden nervous start of fright as we hear Daddy's voice loud on the TRACK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything all right, Doctor? CUT TO A POV shot of Daddy at the rear of the downstairs hall, napkin in hand and hands on hips. He is staring sternly at the doctor. CUT BACK TO the Doctor. He glances nervously again toward Buddy. ANOTHER POV SHOT of Buddy. Looks just like Daddy, hands on hips. ON Dr. Martinson, as he looks back at Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes. Yes. Just fine. A few more days... a little more rest... she'll be perfectly healthy. ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy as he walks forward down the hall toward Buddy. The CAMERA PICKS UP Buddy and both of them grimly stare after the fleeing doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a low, conspiratorial tone) What do you think, Brother?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. But you better watch him like a hawk, if he comes back again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not coming back again. We scared the rascal off, son. (puts a hand on Buddy's shoulder) Come on back to supper. Your mother has a theory about how to educate Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY A SHOT of Mother and Rose and the children in the kitchen. We see a sewing machine and evidences of dressmaking. Rose has on a new and modest little dress that Mother evidently has made for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, Rose? Now that's the kind of dress you ought to wear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (less than enthusiastic) Yeah, it's kinda nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look very pretty in it, Rose. Really, you do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles at Mother) Well, you're real sweet to make it for me. (puts an arm around Mother's shoulder) There never was nobody like you. And you don't need to worry, I ain't goin' out no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, there's no reason you shouldn't go out, Rose... in moderation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little shrug) I don't want to. When I was lyin' there in that hospital bed at death's door I says to myself, I ain't goin' out no more. If I ever get outta this, I'll just stay home. Rose casually pulls the dress over her head and stands there in panties and bra, oblivious of Buddy and the children. She has about as much modesty as a small child herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rather sadly) Besides, there ain't no Mr. Right out there. Or if there is I can't find him, all I find is a pile of Mr. Wrongs. I ain't goin' out no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. CHURCH - DAY A SHOT of Daddy, Mother, Rose, and the children all in their Sunday best going up the steps of a church. Rose looks virginal in the modest dress Mother made for her. INT. CHURCH - DAY A SHOT of Rose, Mother, Daddy and the children on a bench in church. We hear singing. Rose looks innocent, virginal as she sings. Mother gives her an approving look, exchanges glances with Daddy. EXT. CHURCH - DAY CUT TO a shot of the Hillyer family coming out of church. We see them shaking hands with the Minister. Rose smiles sweetly, modestly. EXT. HILLYER DRIVEWAY - DAY CUT TO a shot of the Model A driving up in the driveway of the Hillyer house. ANOTHER ANGLE on them all as they get out of the car. Rose takes Doll's hand with one hand and Waski's hand with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, we'll play monopoly then. Mother, Daddy and Buddy watch Rose go up the steps with Doll and Waski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's like a different person. Being so sick made a big impression on her. I really think she's learned a lesson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um-hmm. (waits as Mother goes on up steps, then turns to Buddy and in a low tone) Come with me, Brother. I want to show you something. EXT. HILLYER HOME - ROSE GARDEN - DAY CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy in a rose garden below the windows of the house. It is Hawkshaw the Detective and his Unwilling Assistant. Daddy solemnly points to dim marks in the flower bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See that, son? Now this is a heel, see, and there, that's the ball of a foot. Someone has been walking here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reluctantly) Well, it's not very plain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is because it rained recently, the rain has obscured the evidence. But you could still take plaster casts of these footprints, then match up the plaster casts with whosever shoes they are, and that way you could catch him -- understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But how would you find him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. Well, what I mean is, you could prove it was his shoes if you did catch him. But look this, Brother, it is even more interesting. Look at this mark here, and that mark over there. Now wouldn't you say those marks are the marks of a ladder?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't know. (trying to sound like a fellow detective, but doesn't want Rose to get caught) No, I don't know, Daddy, I think the rain has obscured it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True, but if you look sharply you can see that those marks are the marks of a ladder. Now let's go back to the garage and see if the ladder has been tampered with. INT. GARAGE - DAY CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy back in the garage. They are scrutinizing a wooden ladder that hangs on pegs alongside the garage. All Daddy needs is a cap and a pipe to be a dead ringer for Sherlock Holmes. He is in dead earnest about this, it is no Joke and he does not dream of being funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (points to ladder, eyes narrowed) See, son? The paint is flaked off here, freshly. Look at it, Brother, there is no question about it. Some person or persons unknown have very recently tampered with this ladder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... maybe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there's only one reason anybody would want this ladder -- to get up into Rose's bedroom in the dark of night! I am going to chain up this ladder and padlock it! -- and that is not all I am going to do! Buddy stares at him in apprehension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - DINING ROOM - NIGHT A shot of the whole family at dinner including Rose. Daddy puts down his napkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was a delicious repast, Rose, as usual. Now I have something of grave import to say to you and to Mrs. Hillyer. (pauses, points at Buddy) And I don't want you children snooping, do you hear me, Brother? Go up to your rooms. INT. HILLYER HOME - UPSTAIRS - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski in the upstairs. They tiptoe along furtively. INT. HILLYER HOME - STAIRCASE - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of the children going down backstairs. INT. HILLYER HOME - CELLAR - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Buddy leading Doll and Waski down the steps of the cellar. The CAMERA follows as they walk past an ancient coal-burning furnace and... INT. HILLYER HOME - CRAWL SPACE - NIGHT climb up into 'a crawl space beneath the front of the house. A shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski crawling along on dirt in the crawl space under the house. They come to a floor heat ventillator grill and stop. Buddy holds his fingers to his lips and listens intently. INT. HILLYER HOME - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Daddy, Mother and Rose in Mother's bedroom study. We see the grillwork of the heat ventillator in the floor. Daddy is at the climax of his speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all love you, Rose. Even more now, since you've bravely surmounted all these epizootics. We admire you, we esteem you, we hold your hand with love and affection, we have an investment in you -- and I don't mean money, although God knows we have that, too, considering those godawful hospital bills... INT. HILLYER HOME - CRAWL SPACE - NIGHT CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Buddy, Doll and Waski in the crawl space. Buddy is smiling in relief. He whispers to Doll and Waski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not going to fire her. INT. HILLYER HOME - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT CUT BACK TO Daddy, Mother and Rose in the bedroom-study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean a human investment, Rose, we care about you, you matter to us. But we have innocent and unformed children in this house and the monkey and dog show has got to stop. Do you hear me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (meekly) Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a bit overwhelmed by Daddy) She hasn't actually done anything...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (very firmly) Just a moment, dear. (turns to Rose and almost sadly) We can't have it, Rose. Can you behave yourself -- or not? That is the question, to behave or not to behave, to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous chastity and keep your skirt down or to hoist it in the light of the moon and make whoopee -- that is the coil shuffling question. (a dramatic pause, then points at her) If you can't behave I am going to fire you and I say it in front of you and Mrs. Hillyer and I mean it. I point my rigid finger right at your nose, Rose, and I stare unwaveringly into your big blue eyes and I tell you... this is a final warning. Do you hear me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (very meekly) Yes, sir. INT. HILLYER HOME - CELLAR - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski as they climb from the crawl space down into the cellar by the furnace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if she's got any sense at all, she'll listen to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sense doesn't mean anything to Rose. But I think we're on safe ground now. Daddy chained up the ladder, whoever it is can't get in the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - BUDDY'S BEDROOM - DAY A shot of Buddy sound asleep in his bed in the early gray dawn. As we DISSOLVE IN on the shot, we hear a loud BANGING and DADDY'S VOICE. DADDY (O.S.) Open that door! Open it up, open it this instant! Do you hear met open that door! Buddy sits quickly up in bed, at once pushes back the covers and gets out of the bed, hurriedly reaches for his khaki pants. INT. HILLYER HOME - UPSTAIRS HALL - DAY CUT TO a shot of Daddy in the upstairs hall. He is fully dressed and is banging angrily on Rose's door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose! Rose! Open this goddamn door! Open it or I'll break it down! ANOTHER ANGLE on Buddy as he hurries down the hall up to Daddy, in khaki pants and pulling a shirt over his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open that door, damn you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy, what's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (glances around at him) She's got somebody in there, Brother! His shoes are on the back porch -- there they were, naked and smiling at me! (bangs on door) Rose, open this door immediately! ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy as he bangs on the door. We see a frightened Doll in her nightgown in the b.g. down the hall, a hand to her mouth. Daddy commences kicking at the door. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE ON Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open up, Rose! Procrastination won't help you! Finally, the CLICK of a bolt and slowly the door opens. We see a wide-eyed, terrified Rose. She has a sheet around her and evidently nothing more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (he pushes past her) All right, where is he? Where's the culprit? INT. HILLYER HOME - ROSE'S BEDROOM - DAY CUT TO a shot of Daddy in the bedroom. He yanks open the closet door, looks under the bed as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he? I know he's in here, where is he, Rose? His shoes were on the back porch I smiling at met Where are you, you son of a bitch? In her distress and dismay, the sheet has come down over Rose's shoulder and one of her breasts is exposed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (feebly, she is terrified) There ain't nobody here, Mr. Hillyer! Honest, there ain't!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he? Where have you got him hid? (notices curtain blowing in wide open window) Ah, ha! The CAMERA follows Daddy as he strides angrily toward the window and leans out of it and stares down. Rose makes a little whimpering sound. EXT. HILLYER SOME - GARDEN - DAWN CUT TO a POV shot of the garden below as seen by Daddy from the window. We see lying on the ground BILLY, the Sulky Boy who scared Mother. He wears only undershorts and is groaning, holding his leg, which evidently he has injured in jumping from the window. INT. HILLYER HOME - ROSE'S BEDROOM - DAWN On Daddy, as he turns from the window to Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who, Rose, may I ask, is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's Billy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what, may I ask, was Billy doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a straight answer) Well, Mr. Hillyer, Billy's very poor, he don't have no money and there wasn't no place else to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it was a silly question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a nice boy, you'd like him. He wants to be a fireman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ye gods and little fishes, a fireman. Put on some clothes, Rose, you're naked as a jay bird. When you're dressed, come on downstairs. I'm afraid your friend Billy is injured, where are his clothes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (begins weeping, both breasts now are exposed) Under the mattress. I hid 'em so you wouldn't be mad. He wants to marry me, he loves me. I can't marry him, he's too young and hasn't got no job, but he loves me... now you wouldn't hurt him, would you? Daddy gently pulls the sheet around her to cover her breasts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't hurt him, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY A shot of Daddy, Mother and Rose at the kitchen table drinking coffee in the early morning. Daddy looks grave, Mother looks sad, and Rose is crying into a handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Hillyer, I know it was bad and I hadn't ought to of done it. But I'm only a human girl and I... I ain't always perfect. I promise I won't let him in the house no more, I promise. Won't you and Mrs. Hillyer forgive me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose, darlin', you break my heart. But I am only a human man myself of the father variety. Rose, pack your bag, baby, as of this moment you are hired, mired and fired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - DINING ROOM - DAY A shot of the family at breakfast in the dining room. The dissolve suggests that some time has gone by. Daddy looks a bit grim, Rose has a wan and depressed expression. Mother looks worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (politely) Well, Rose, going out to look for a job today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes down) What's the use, there ain't none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmm. Would you get me another half a-cup of coffee, dear? Rose rises and he watches her leave, then turns to Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has been three weeks since I "fired" her. Is there no way to get rid of this girl? Are we stuck with her for life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't get a job, it's a depression. And we can't just throw her out on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hell we can't. Rose returns with coffee and pours it out for Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose, you don't look well and you haven't eaten a bit of breakfast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not hungry. I can't eat nothin', I haven't been able to eat since I got fired. I think maybe I'm sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God forbid. You're not sick, Rose, forget it. Don't get any notions in your head, you're not sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does look a little peaky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she doesn't, she's fine, fine. She's perfectly healthy, don't give her ideas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll do the dishes, then I'm goin' to lie down a minute and rest. My stomach hurts. Daddy watches Rose exit to the kitchen, then leans forward and speaks to Mother, his expression a bit sly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her plan is obvious, plain as day. She's going on a hunger strike. The question is, how do we foil her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's just nervous and worried. And you would be, too, if you had no job and no place to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (thinking hard) Something has got to be done or Rose is going to be in this house forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. HILLYER HOME - DRIVEWAY AND PATIO - DAY A shot of the Model A coming up the driveway of the Hillyer House. It is late afternoon. CUT TO a shot of Daddy getting out of the car. He has a triumphant little smile on his face. A shot of Daddy as he walks onto the patio, a rolled-up copy of the Glenville Tribune in his hand and his straw hat on the back of his head. He definitely has a triumphant expression. Buddy on the patio notices it. INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY CUT TO a shot of the kitchen on Mother and Rose. Mother is helping a rather wan Rose prepare dinner. Enter Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as if everyone will be pleased) Well, I have got news! I called long distance and spoke to Cousin Hop and you'll be glad to know, Rose, I have found you a job!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tennessee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Tennessee, a lovely state!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. What kinda job is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ahh-hh, you'll like it. It's a fine, outdoor-type job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean a farm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, not exactly. It isn't a farm in the sense that it's a farm. Not at all. It's a... dairy establishment. You'll 1ike it! I'm sure you'll like it because it's so... peaceful! Rose bows her head and begins crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think -- DADDY Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds like a farm to me. Calling it a dairy establishment, that's just trickery and flummery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trickery and flummery or not, she's going there tomorrow on the bus! It's settled! And I must say we've been more than fair to you, Rose, it's pretty selfish and mean hearted of you to sit there and cry like that! Rose sits head bowed at the kitchen table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not cryin' because of me, I'm cryin' because of somebody else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stops in mid-air, so to speak) What? EXT. HILLYER HOME - PATIO - DAY CUT TO a shot of Buddy outside on the patio, listening intently at the window. He leans forward with a keen interest, eyes wide. INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Daddy. He is peering intently at Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you say, Rose? CLOSE ON Rose, as she turns, weeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I was born on a farm myself... and I hate to think of the baby being born on one. On them all. Daddy and Mother stare in shock at Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What baby? What baby? What baby are you speaking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your baby?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, mine. I'm going to have one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (he is "poleaxed," staggered) Good God almighty. This is a catastrophe, they won't hire her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looks up, sees Buddy in patio window) Brother, get out of that window! Buddy ducks down out of eight instantly. Both Mother and Daddy, however, are too preoccupied and upset to be concerned with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stares off groggily into space) This is a total catastrastroke. As of this moment I am stumped, I admit, I am stumped and treed both, the hound dogs have me surrounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as Rose begins crying) Poor thing, don't cry, Rose. I know you feel awful, but don't cry, honey, nobody's perfect. Who's the father, dear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I... I... I don't know... maybe it was... but no, you can't be sure about a thing like that. It wasn't Billy, I didn't know him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gently) I know it's embarrassing... but who were you exposed to, dear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, now, Mrs. Hillyer, I... ah-h, that's kinda hard to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not going to get anywhere with that line of questioning. The problem is, what are we going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I'm asking her who the father is. It's the most vital question of all. Who's the father, dear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offhand; he is thinking hard about what to do) She already told you, she doesn't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (naively) But she must know... unless... unless... Rose, was there more than one person?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (weeping in handkerchief) Oh-h, Mrs. Hillyer, I... I can't think. I... I'm not really sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gently, a tiny frown, a bit shocked) Rose, really, you shouldn't act like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (weeping) Oh, I know. But I didn't, really. Honestly, I didn't. There was only one, but he's out of town and leave no forwardin' address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a brilliant idea) Ah, ha! Hold the phone! No forwarding address, huh? (turns to Mother) In the shock of this brilliant move, I forgot something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you forget?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I forgot that Rose will lie like a child. She's no more pregnant than I am, she just doesn't want to go to that farm!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you're not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Hillyer, I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (triumphant, sure he's right) All right, tell us, Rose, what makes you think you're pregnant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (simply) I haven't had my period for three months and my stomach is getting big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (again "poleaxed" for a moment, but pulls himself together) I don't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so, Mr. Hillyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, damn it. We've seen you with your clothes off around here, stand up and pull up your dress and let's take a look!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't have to take her panties off, we can see her stomach with 'em on. All she has to do is pull up her dress and let us see her belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, all right, if you just won't believe me. Rose stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose, you don't have to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, you will see, she's lying like she always does -- that belly will be flat as a pancake! Rose lifts her dress and Daddy leans forward eagerly to confirm his belief. Rose stands there with her skirt lifted. She has on a pair of skimpy white panties. An unmistakable, definite protrusion can be seen in the area below her navel just above the line of her panties. A stupefied look is on Daddy's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd say about three months. Are you satisfied?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am poleaxed and in a non compos mentis condition. I wash my hands or the whole thing. EXT. HILLYER HOME - PATIO - DAY CUT TO a shot of Doll walking up onto the patio with schoolbooks. The CAMERA follows her as she walks over to Buddy, who is crouched down eavesdropping at another window. She whispers to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's goin' on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose says she's goin' to have a baby and she sure looks it, but I don't think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A baby... and she isn't even married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the least of her troubles. Rose had a rare tropic disease and the little tubes in her that babies swim down are all stopped up, she told me all about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it isn't a baby... what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. DR. MARTINSON'S HOME OFFICE WAITING ROOM - NIGHT A shot of Buddy and Rose in a rather elegant Doctor's waiting room. It is night and they are alone on a small sofa. Buddy has a very solemn and worried look. Rose lies weeping in terror on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Buddy, they're gonna cut me all up! They're gonna cut my stummick all open, I'll die!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to be brave) You won't die, Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy, I'm scared, I'm scared! INT. DR. MARTINSON'S SOME OFFICE - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Dr. Martinson's private office in his home, quite a bit more luxurious than his office at the hospital. A sober-looking Mother and Daddy sit talking to him. He almost seems to relish the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not surprised you thought she was pregnant. An ovarian cyst can look very much like pregnancy. But it was pure wishful thinking on her part. The girl can never have children, she had gonorrhea at fifteen and it was untreated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shocked, rather feebly) Gonorrhea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Madam, she can't infect your dear little kiddies. She long ago fully recovered, but the disease did irreparable damage. The girl is permanently barren.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's pathetic. Poor Rose, what a life she has had.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We make our own lives, Madam. As for malignancy, I don't think so, it's very unlikely. I probably shouldn't have even mentioned that possibility to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rather coldly, seems disenchanted with him) No, you shouldn't have, it was needlessly cruel. She thinks she has cancer and is going to die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's an adult, Mrs. Hillyer, I was merely giving her the facts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's a disaster. I don't know what to say, Doctor, I am floored. How dangerous is the operation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any major operation is dangerous. However, as we know from her previous illness, she's a very strong girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if it isn't malignant and she can get through the operation all right, it might be better than her really being pregnant. She doesn't even know who the father might have been.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's definitely better, beyond question. A fatherless child, an ignorant girl with no job, no money, no home. It's fortunate, a blessing really, and a stroke of good luck for another reason I want to mention to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (totally disenchanted with the Doctor) This conversation is making me a little sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, that's no way to talk to the Doctor, he's merely doing his job, dear. Oddly enough, in the stress of the situation, Daddy now seems almost friendly to Dr. Martinson, whom previously he considered a polecat. INT. DR. MARTINSON'S HOME OFFICE WAITING ROOM - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Buddy and Rose in the waiting room. He is helping her lie on the couch on pillows as she weeps, a hand over her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta find out what they're saying. You lie back and rest, Rose, and I'll give you a report on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to know... INT. DR. MARTINSON'S HOME OFFICE - NIGHT CUT TO a CLOSE shot of Dr. Martinson. An expression of distaste is on his face. The CAMERA pulls back as he talks to Mother and Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry the truth nauseates you, Mrs. Hillyer, because before you leave there's a bit more of it I'd like to put to you. This operation provides a therapeutic opportunity that I feel is quite important in regard to this particular girl, who suffers not only from an ovarian cyst but from a certain psychoneurotic condition as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, what kind of gobbledygook talk is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead, Doctor, I think I am following you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gives Mother an aloof glance, then to Daddy) First, about the girl's history. Evidently she's been very promiscuous since early childhood, she has no control over her sexual impulses. Furthermore, she is permanently barren, she can't have children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, Doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly) Yes, go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am thinking particularly of the other ovary. As a rule I don't believe in removing it. The woman's hormonal system is profoundly disturbed, she is subject to possibly serious depression, she loses many of her secondary sexual characteristics for example, her breasts might shrink and become flabby, facial hair might appear along with a coarsening of the features, and of course her sexual drive is greatly diminished, especially in a girl or young woman. For these reasons I am opposed to removing the other ovary, as a rule. Do you follow me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am ahead of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then... may I speak quite frankly with you, Mr. Hillyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have of course observed the girl in treating her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we both know her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we know her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? I don't understand all this mumbo jumbo and the funny looks on your faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Hillyer, this girl is sick in more ways than one. She is an extreme psychoneurotic with uncontrollable sexual impulses. It would be a mercy to spare her the suffering she causes herself and others. Therefore I recommend as a therapeutic measure the removal of her second ovary. It is ethically and medically the only proper decision in this case and I suspect your husband agrees with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctantly, I do. It would be a blessing to her and everyone else. The girl is oversexed and I say -- spay her!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slowly rises to her feet and in a trembling voice) Over... my... dead... body! A long, frozen pause as both Daddy and Dr. Martinson stare at Mother in surprise. She stares at the Doctor with fire in her eyes. He seems already to shrink a little. Finally she speaks with a calm fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you human beings or are you some kind of male monsters? Is there no limit to which you won't go to keep your illusions about yourselves?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrinking a little) Illusions, Madam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd go so far as to mutilate a helpless girl who has no means to defend herself, you'd go that far? Don't you think I know what you've just said and don't you think I understand the dreadful and revolting crime you've just conspired to commit? Dr. Martinson stares at her in fear and shock, intimidated by the calm fury and ice-cold moral indignation. He opens his mouth as if to speak, but no sound comes out. Mother turns to Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I knew you. I thought I knew you better, I thought in your heart you were a good and kind man. Well, I can't believe what I've just heard in this room. A defenseless girl depending on you for protection, and you propose to mutilate and destroy her. How could you listen even for a moment to that sadistic man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slightly shattered) Well, now, darlin'... give me a chance to defend myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe you really meant it, if I did I'd want to die. You aren't a male monster, that man is but you aren't. Look me in the eye and tell me, do you really want to take Rose's womanhood away from her when it's all she has got?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I... I hadn't thought about it that much. I was thinking... well, it's an idea, the girl is oversexed, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose isn't oversexed, that's ridiculous. If you're going to talk nonsense, I don't want to talk to you at all. Rose is exactly the same as the rest of us, except more so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I know, more so. That's why I was thinking... maybe she'd be better off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with a quiet fury) Better off? How could she ever find love and happiness, if you did what you're talking about? Are you insane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rather feebly) Now, may I say, I am against that particular procedure, as a general rule. But in a case of near nymphomania, it doesn't seem monstrous to me at all, but medically advisable. Both Mother and Daddy totally ignore him. Mother's eyes are fixed on Daddy and he is struggling with himself, staring down at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, now, I admit... in Rose's case, it would be cruel. If Rose wasn't attractive and pretty... well, it would probably be bad for almost any young woman. I don't know exactly what I was thinking about, the doctor said it and it sounded reasonable. Daddy finally looks up at Mother and admits his error like a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're right, darlin', you're absolutely dead right, it would be an awful and horrible thing to do. I'm sorry, honey, forgive me, I didn't mean it. Mother turns from Daddy and walks up to the desk and stares down at Dr. Martinson as if he is a loathesome bug upon which she intends to step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not cry like a woman. If I'm upset it's because of what my husband said, not because of you. You can't make me cry like a woman, a woman has got just as much intelligence and self-control as a man. And you get this in your head. If you hurt that girl, I'll hire lawyers and sue you for malpractice for every penny you have got, I'll do my level best to ruin you. Do you understand me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a sickly smile, he is licked totally) Yes, I understand you, but you have misunderstood me completely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (icy cold) I understand you perfectly. You leave that girl alone, you wretched man, or you will be sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a foolish smile, as if Mother has paid him some kind of compliment) Actually of course I won't operate, I don't do major surgery. Dr. Hardy will operate and of course he'll be guided by your wishes in this respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him be guided not by my wishes and not by Rose's wishes, although I am sure they are identical. Let him be guided by the wishes of the creative power of life itself, because that is what has spoken through me tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. STREET BY HOSPITAL - DAY A shot of the Model A parked on the street outside a hospital in a small Southern town. We see Daddy slowly pacing back and forth in front of the hospital entrance, his head bowed and his hands clasped behind him. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSER on the Model A. Buddy sits in the middle on the front seat, Mother is at the window. Doll and Waski are on the back seat. They all are staring with pale worry at the pacing Daddy fifty feet away. All are frightened, Mother is very pale. Doll has a tiny handkerchief to her eyes and is half crying. Even Waski is very scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (seems on verge of tears) Mother... is Rose going to die?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a trembly voice) No, Waski, she won't die, because we are praying for her. CUT TO a shot of Daddy from the POV of the car. He looks at his wristwatch, frowns and walks into the entrance of the hospital. ANOTHER ANGLE, on them all in the car. They wait, pale and silent. Doll sniffles in her handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is it taking so long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes Daddy. CUT TO a POV shot of Daddy as he slowly walks up to the car, his straw hat in his hand. CUT TO a shot of Mother CLOSE on her face as she stares at her husband as if trying to read the news on his face. A tiny frown comes on her forehead as icy fear comes in her eyes. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Daddy as he walks up to the window of the car, hat in hand. A trace of tears can be seen in his eyes, but when he speaks his voice is calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (philosophically) Well, I thought I'd seen the limit, but these are the most great, gaga epizootics she's ever had. ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy and them all. In pale fear, mother stares at him, uncertain what has happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. As mother sighs in heartfelt relief...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY A shot of Daddy sitting with mother at the kitchen table. Bright cheerful sunshine comes in the window that opens on the patio. Rose comes into the SHOT carrying a coffee pot, a sunny smile on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking very chipper this morning, Rose. Sow do you feel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perfect, wonderful, good as I ever felt! Except for a big old scar on my stummick, I wouldn't even know I been in the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with mild irony, as she pours him coffee) Well, we know you were there. The bill that hospital sent was absolutely horrendous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (her smile fades a trifle) Well, I'll pay you that back sometime, Mr. Hillyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it, honey. Daddy pauses, seems to be struggling with himself, he is frowning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rose... I hate to be mean, but... (another pause, then a little shrug) Oh, nevermind, forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a little sad voice) What was it, Mr. Hillyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rises) Nothing, Rose. Daddy stops beside her, puts an arm around her shoulders and with weary irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all love you, darlin'. Daddy wearily picks up his straw hat from the kitchen counter and walks out of the kitchen on the patio, as the CAMERA stays on Rose and mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, honey, you'll find something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was offered that job as a waitress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget about it, I don't want you working in one of those honky tonks. EXT. HILLYER HOME - PATIO - DAY CUT TO a shot of Buddy on the patio. He has eight or nine gourds on an outdoor table and is cutting round holes in them and emptying out the seed. He glances up as Rose walks up to him, pocketbook in hand. She seems a little sad. But she smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Buddy. (puts an arm around his shoulders) How's my sweetheart who never told on me when I was bad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (picks up a hollowed out gourd) Makin' homes for purple martins, huh? We had 'em on the farm. They're the prettiest things. That's what I wish I was, a bird. Just fly around catch bugs and have a lot of fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you going to do, Rose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a little walk with me, huh? EXT. HILLYER HOME - GARDEN CUT TO a shot of Rose and Buddy on a beautiful summer day walking in the garden behind the Hillyer house. They walk up to an empty rabbit hutch. The hutch is made of rough lumber and chicken wire and has cubicles for about a dozen rabbits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as she stares at the empty hutch) I guess I'll work as a waitress, Buddy. I done that before and it got me in worse trouble than you could know, but I can't stay here no more. Why did you get rid of your rabbits, Buddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dumb things. I got tired of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles, touches chicken wire) Did you know when I was a child we had pretty near five hundred rabbits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five hundred rabbits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep, we had 'em in orange crates all over. It was Daddy's dream. He was goin' to get rich raisin' rabbits. It was what killed Daddy. He didn't drown hisself till a long time later after Momma and Lunette died of typhoid, but it was them rabbits what killed him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did the rabbits kill him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thought he could sell 'em, but nobody but country folks eat rabbits, Buddy, and they ain't got no money. We had to eat them dern rabbits our own selves. Every dern one, and it took about four years to eat 'em all up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little smile) Well, that doctor said you got protein somewhere and I guess he was right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy did I get sick of rabbit. But later on after Momma died and Daddy wasn't doin' nothin' but drinkin', I sure would of been glad for a little rabbit stew. You know, I oughtn't to of told you about what Daddy done when I was a child. Until them rabbits ruined him, he was a real good man, Buddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was your mother like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A saint just like your own mother. She's up in heaven right now, her and Lunette, there ain't no doubt about it. ANOTHER ANGLE as Buddy and Rose walk away hand in hand away from the rabbit hutch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it was eating all those rabbits that made you sexy, Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy, sex don't mean a thing to me. It ain't nothin' but a mosquito bite. (stops, smiles, puts an arm around his shoulders) I'll tell you a secret. Girls don't want sex, Buddy, girls want love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HILLYER HOME - LIVING ROOM NIGHT A shot of Mother and Daddy in the Hillyer living room late at night. Mother sits with a worried expression on a chair, a kimono around her shoulders. Daddy is pacing worriedly in pajamas and a bathrobe. He looks at his wristwatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's twenty after one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand it. Even in the wild days she was never as late as this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid it's my fault. I made her feel guilty this morning -- (glances around, sees something in doorway) Brother, what are you doing up? ANOTHER ANGLE on Buddy in pajamas as he enters the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you talking. Hasn't Rose come in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she hasn't. (frowns, looks around) I think I hear a car. EXT. HILLYER HOME - DRIVEWAY CUT TO a shot of a 1930's automobile in the Hillyer driveway at night as it drives up and stops before the front steps. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Rose and Dave Wilkie in the car. Here DAVE is much YOUNGER, of course, and a rather handsome man in a stolid way. Even though he is younger than when we saw him on the plane, he is quite a bit older than Rose. Rose's eyes are opened wide, she is a bit breathless, obviously something important has happened. Dave stares at her as if fascinated, almost as if awed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rather stiffly) I want to thank you for a wonderful afternoon and evenin'. Can I see you in the mornin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a bit breathless) Yes. Year you can, you sure can. INT. HILLYER HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Daddy peering out of the window of the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, that looks like Dave Wilkie,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Dave, his wife used to do dressmaking for you before she died. EXT. HILLYER HOME - FRONT STEPS - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of Rose on the steps. Happy as a clam, she turns and waves at Dave in the car, then goes on up the steps. INT. HILLYER HOME - FRONT HALL - NIGHT CUT TO a shot of the front hall as Rose comes through the front door. She is very excited, happy. INT. HILLYER HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT The CAMERA follows her as she goes into the living room with her big news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never guess what happened! (pauses, then dramatically) I have met Mr. Right! I been with him all day and he loves me, I know he does, he loves me and he's going to marry met Be's practi'cly ast me already!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... well, that's wonderful, Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who do you suppose he is? That policeman who arrested me, the one I bit! He is Mr. Right!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. CHURCH - DAY VARIOUS SHOTS of a wedding in a tiny country church. We see shots of Rose in a white wedding dress, smiling, happy. Dave is stiff and solemn in his best suit. Daddy gravely gives Rose away. We hear no dialogue here, MUSIC on track. We see Mother, Buddy, Doll and Waski in the front row, all in Sunday best and very solemn. We see a CLOSE SHOT of Rose's knees trembling beneath her white wedding dress as a country minister marries them. VARIOUS SHOTS of a rather idyllic country wedding in a very plain, unpretentious country church, and... DISSOLVE TO: EXT. CHURCH - DAY A shot of Rose, Dave, Buddy, Doll and Waski at a picnic celebration outside the church by a running brook. The scene should be beautiful in summertime. We see a barbecue pit, homemade ice cream in the metal can, other picnic things. A happy Rose is kissing first Buddy, then Doll, then Waski. Dave smiles fondly, but rather stiffly at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now Waski, are you and Buddy and Dolly ready for some ice cream, huh? Do you like picnics or don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We like 'em! We love 'em!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it isn't a picnic, honey. It's a barbecue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little smile) Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A picnic doesn't involve roast meat, hon. At a barbecue you have a lot of roast meat. CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Buddy as he stares pensively at Dave. The CAMERA stays on him as we hear VOICES OVER. Rose is happy, Dave phlegmatic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, all I know is there's ice cream. And I'm gonna have me a plate right now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better wait, hon. It'll spoil your appetite. Have some barbecue first. The CAMERA stays on Buddy, as he stares pensively at Dave. He has no expression on his face at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. CHURCH - DAY A shot of Rose and Dave bidding goodbye to the Hillyers. Daddy, Mother, Buddy, Doll and Waski are in the model A. Rose is obviously on the verge of tears as Dave speaks solemnly to Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we are off to Savannah, Mr. Hillyer. No more police work, I'm getting in the construction field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, Dave. And good luck to you, too, Rosebud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (begins crying) Oh, Mr. Hillyer! I just can't stand to say goodbye! Daddy starts the Model A.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you all! Goodbye, Buddy! Goodbye, Dolly! Goodbye, Waski! ANOTHER ANGLE on Rose as she weeps and waves the handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye! Goodbye!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT./EXT. MODEL A - STREET - DAY A shot of Daddy and Mother in the Model A as Daddy drives. We see Doll and Waski solemn on the back seat, but Buddy is not visible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, thank God we are rid of her at last. And the best thing of all is that she's happy. The little nut is happy, she found Mr. Right in the nick of time!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, yes, she's happy. Of course Dave doesn't have her life force, not at all. There isn't much furniture in his house, just a table and one or two chairs, whereas Rose has furniture coming out of the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, he is Mr. Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slowly nods) Yes, I think so. He adores her, it's almost pitiful the way he worships her. I just hope she isn't too much for him. Mother pauses, frowning, she has her doubts, looks over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think, Brother? Mother frowns in surprise. CUT TO a POV shot of Buddy on the back seat of the car. Now it is clear why we couldn't see him in the other shot. Be is lying down on the seat of the car with his Sunday coat pulled over his head. ANOTHER ANGLE on Mother and Buddy, Doll, Waski. Buddy lies on the seat, motionless with his coat over his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (seems awed, staring down at Buddy) I don't know. I think he's cryin'! CUT TO ANOTHER ANGLE on Mother, from the front as she slowly turns back and stares thoughtfully ahead. The shot is also on Daddy. They both stare ahead in pensive silence. Finally Mother speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rather sadly) Maybe Brother is right. Maybe so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : END OF FLASHBACK INT./EXT. HERTZ CAR ON INTERSTATE - DAY ON Willcox Hillyer behind the wheel of the Hertz car. He is staring pensively ahead, a faint trace of tears in his eyes. It is a very faint trace, a look of mild irony and amusement is on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (dryly, to himself) Mr. Right. Dave Wilkie. Willcox slowly shakes his head. EXT. HERTZ CAR - INTERSTATE EXIT - DAY CUT TO a shot of the red Ford as it takes a turn-off from an Interstate. EXT. HERTZ CAR - BUSTLING CITY - DAY CUT TO a shot of the red Ford as it drives into a rather bustling little Southern city that does not look at all like the "Glenville" we have seen. A lot of traffic, new roads, filling stations, prosperity. It could be Rome, Georgia as it is today. EXT. CAR PAST HOLIDAY INN - DAY ANOTHER SHOT of the red Ford going past a modern Holiday Inn in the city. EXT. HILLYER HOME - DRIVEWAY - DAY ON the red Ford as it turns into a familiar driveway, that of the old Hillyer home. But insofar as possible it looks different now, like a relic from the past. Maybe the house needs painting, the garden is in weeds -- the place is not exactly dilapidated, but it is marked by time. A SHOT of Willcox Hillyer as he gets out of the red Ford and walks up the familiar steps of the front porch, travel bag in hand. EXT. HILLYER HOME - FRONT PORCH - DAY ON Willcox Hillyer at the front door. He tries the knob, opens the door and goes inside. INT. HILLYER HOME - FRONT HALL - DAY CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer as he glances into the living room. The room looks the same but different -it is musty, dim. Willcox Hillyer stares at it as if haunted a bit, turns and the CAMERA follows him as he crosses the hall and looks into Mother's old bedroom-study. This room is quite different. The four poster is gone. The room is dusty, musty, dark. Magazines are on the floor in a ring around Mother's old study chair. We see "male" things. It is apparent Daddy lives alone in this room. A SHOT of Willcox Hillyer as he walks down the familiar hall back to the kitchen. INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY He looks around. No one is there. He glances at a modern refrigerator that is in pretty poor shape, glances with a frown at dishes in the sink unwashed. He goes on out to the patio. EXT. HILLYER HOME - PATIO - DAY CUT TO a shot of Daddy putting out seed for birds on a table on the patio. Daddy now is a very old man, but his personality and style are the same as ever. He looks up with a stern frown as Willcox Hillyer comes out on the patio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you rascal, where'd you come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Daddy. How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About as good as can be expected with one foot in the grave. Good to see you, son. (they shake hands) Did you bring any of that Yankee whisky with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't Yankee whisky, Daddy, it's Scotch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Yankee whisky to me. Daddy takes him by the arm, leads him back into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you stand it up there, boy, in all that ice and snow? What are you, a polar bear? INT. HILLYER HOME - KITCHEN - DAY CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer and Daddy as they enter the kitchen. The former opens his travel bag and takes out a bottle of Teacher's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can use a drink after the plane ride I had.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your wife and children are back in New Hampshire in the snow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little smile; it is summer, there couldn't be snow in New Hampshire) Yeah, they're in the snow. Willcox opens whisky, looks for glasses in the dusty familiar cupboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are they polar bears, too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (frowns at cupboard) Good God, the way you live here. This place hasn't been dusted since Mother died. Look at that goddamned refrigerator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got another twenty years in it, boy. (something seems to be bothering him) By the way, son, do you recall Rose, that pretty blonde girl who came to our house way back in 1935 or 1936 and caused such a damnable commotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (frowns, turns and stares at him) Of course I recall Rose. In fact I've been thinking of no one else for the last hour and a half.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could that be, son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave Wilkie of all people was sitting by me on the plane -- her first husband. It's funny you would mention Rose. Did you hear from her? Willcox pours out whisky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (casually) Well, yes, in a manner of speaking. You'll have the back bedroom, son, Mother's old art room. Just be careful going down the stairs you don't break your Yankee neck. EXT. HILLYER HOME - PATIO - DAY CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer and Daddy as they walk with their drinks out to the patio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's all this about Rose? What do you mean, you heard from her in a manner of speaking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I heard from her, I got a letter from her, she's fine. But there is some sad news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What sad news? Did her cancer come back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, no, she got all over that. Rose is fine. Let's sit down, son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is her husband sick or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's another thing. I was going to write you about it, but since you were coming down anyway I thought I'd wait till you got here. What did Dave Wilkie have to say? ANOTHER ANGLE on Willcox Hillyer and the aged Daddy as they sit on the patio sipping whisky. Willcox Hillyer is not disturbed or worried about Rose, Daddy has been very casual and offhand about it and he has no inkling of what the news really is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pitiful son of a bitch said Rose was a nymphomaniac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um-hmm, and I suppose that incensed you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're damn right it incensed me, the miserable bastard. He also said the kikes and the niggers have taken over Washington. D.C.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods somberly) Yeah, I know, he was up here. It's pitiful like you say. When he lost Rose it ruined the man, it destroyed him totally when he lost Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't lose her, he threw her away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I guess he did. He threw her away and it was the mistake of his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (staring off pensively into space) You know, I don't know this town any more. All this traffic, new buildings, prosperity... (pauses, almost as if in pain) Where have the years gone, Daddy? Where is the little town I knew as a boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At rest in the creative universe with Mother, son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little smile) That's what she would say herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (simply, he is not emoting) A wonderful woman, boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It always gives me a funny feeling to come home. Dear old Southland. Gone. It's all gone, Daddy -- (a fond little smile)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: except you, you're still here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (matter-of-factly) Not for long, boy. I've outstayed my welcome already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's funny you would mention Rose, I was thinking about her all the way up in the car. (gives him a glance) Or maybe it isn't so funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as if in previous thought) I'm older than hell, boy. But this Yankee whisky is mighty fine, I'll say that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Daddy. We have our drink, we're out on the patio, you have prepared me for it. Rose's cancer has come back, hasn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (simply, quietly) No, son, she is dead. WILLCOX HILLYER (numb with shock, for a moment can't speak or think) Dead, Rose is dead? You mean... she died?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am afraid so, son. About a week ago. Her husband phoned me, she had asked him to call me if anything happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in awful shock) But... but how? She was young! Rose wasn't old!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was fifty-six, son. Of course she didn't look it, nowhere near it. The cancer came back, I'm afraid I fibbed about that. But it was very quick, son. She was in the hospital only two weeks, and the last week she didn't know anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in distress, a slightly choked voice) Excuse me, I'll be right back. Willcox Hillyer rises with his drink in hand and walks across the patio to the kitchen door. INT. HILLYER HOME KITCHEN - DAY CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer as he goes into the kitchen. He picks up the whisky bottle and pours himself a very large drink. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Willcox Hillyer as he stares across the kitchen lost in thought.
direction.name: direction
